summary: This document is a series of internal emails from July 23, 2019, among staff at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, discussing an incident involving inmate Jeffrey Epstein. The emails describe how Epstein was found with marks on his neck, placed on suicide watch, and the subsequent medical and psychological assessments. They also discuss plans to move him to general population and coordination with his attorneys.

connections.description: The Operations Lieutenant was the responding officer who found Epstein in distress in his cell and initiated the emergency response.
The Physician Assistant conducted a medical assessment of Epstein following the incident, documenting his physical condition and statements.
The Psychologist evaluated Epstein's mental state and made the determination to keep him on suicide watch.
The Associate Warden is overseeing the administrative response to the incident, including plans for Epstein's housing and reporting to superiors.

events.title: Epstein Found with Neck Injuries in SHU
events.description: At approximately 1:27 a.m., staff responded to a call in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) and found inmate Jeffrey Epstein on the floor in a fetal position with red marks on his neck. He was placed in restraints, escorted to a suicide cell, and placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Medical Assessment of Epstein
events.description: At 6:30 a.m., a Physician Assistant medically assessed Epstein. Findings noted a circular line of erythema on his neck, another on his knee, and that Epstein was ambulatory, oriented, smiling, and denied knowing what happened or having pain.

events.title: Psychological Assessment and Continued Suicide Watch
events.description: At 9:10 a.m., a psychologist evaluated Epstein and determined he should remain on suicide watch for further observation.

events.title: Plans to Move Epstein to General Population
events.description: MCC staff discussed reviewing Epstein's case for placement in the general population in Unit 7 South and were looking for an appropriate cellmate.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York, 150 Park Row, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell in a fetal position with red marks on his neck, leading staff to believe he may have been attacked.
Epstein alleged to staff that his cellmate had attempted to kill him and had been harassing him, and that he had informed his attorney of this matter.
Medical assessment found physical evidence (erythema) on Epstein's neck and knee, but Epstein was ambulatory, oriented, smiling, and claimed not to know what happened.
Epstein was placed and remained on suicide watch following psychological evaluation, while administration simultaneously planned his move to general population.
Internal MCC emails show coordination issues and a need to clarify the incident for reporting to higher authorities like the BOP Director.
